Notes: St, Domingo was at the time a Spanish port. Condemned for lack of register or sea-letter (claim was that the papers were in the chest taken by the privateer).
Crew of Two Friends put on board the Industry of Charleston, bound to Jacmel; not sure whether the actual Two Friends ended up in Jacmel or not
Crew and captain were released at Cabo Raxa, told that the prize would be adjudicated in St. Domingo, but no evidence that it ever happened (crew returned to USA)

captain presented memorials to the Spanish government at St. Jago to prevent the privateer from taking his cargo; government refused but did at least keep the privateer from unloading the cargo at St. Jago. Cargo was condemned at Gonaives but ship was released.
record of ship arriving at the cape but no information about its adjudication; only a protest by Tobias Ham, its master
vessel deserted
Almy captured off the northeast end of Jamaica, but recaptured by HMS Jamaica on 10/13/1799
Condemned because it came from Demerara, even though it was sent to Demerara by HMS Favorite, which stopped it from entering Surinam, its actual destination.
Cargo sequestered and crew released
Cargo condemned

Protest claims that privateer gave chase while flying English colors until it was right up alongside, "which is contrary to the laws of war"; ship was looted while it was at Mont Christy; ship was condemned for going to a British port even though the decree forbidding that was not passed for another 10 days after the capture.
At this time, 3 men were pressed into British navy and replaced by 3 Dutch mariners.
Ship taken to Porto Rico but no record of the adjudication.
Deponent testifies that ship was stolen without any formal trial at all. When deponent asked governor to intervene, the governor declined. Master went to Gonaives to protest.

Condemned because Jeremie "is one of the colonial ports in rebellion against the French republic, and under protection of the British Government, declared in a state of siege by the arret of the commission of the 6th of this month."
No French ports close enough to send the ship in to, since Spanish and USA had trade agreement that prevented ship from being condemned at St. Augustine; ship was ransomed off St. Augustine.
Brig's master was able to retake vessel and proceeded to Kingston as planned.

Condemned because Milton claimed her destination was St. Croix but was really Barbados or Martinique (this statement seems to be backed up by the master's protest--that he really was going to Martinique); she had no sea-letter; her supercargo was Irish and only naturalized American.

Captor: Le Droit de L'Homme and L'Escamoteur
Notes: Condemned because it was carrying pitch and tar, which were contraband bound for a British port.
Condemned for want of a sea-letter
Proceedings of case sent to Madrid, but ship and cargo sent to Ceuta
No proper sailing documents but no certain condemned
originally papers were fine and the French were planning to release but then started dragging their feet.
Guess of the privateer name based on name of captain, Cadet, who was recorded as captain of Passepartout on a different capture.
Cargo sold but ship released
Released after producing a sea-letter, but also plundered.
Condemned for trading with British port
captured off Havana
After being brought to St. Martins, cut out by British lugger and carried to Tortola.
Recaptured by British ship of war
Condemned without a trial.
plundered but not sent to any port as prize
after a long determination, acquitted
crew and captain imprisoned
boarded by French brig and looted but released
cargo condemned and ship released
condemned for want of a sea-letter
recaptured by British vessel before reaching porto rico
crew recaptured the vessel en route to St. Domingo
robbed by French privateer but then released
carrying horses

captured in sight of Deseada
cargo sequestered but ship cleared
Eliza sprung a leak on the way from Cork to NY and bore away for West Indies; was run on shore at Mariegalanta by a privateer; captain was imprisoned 32 days and then released.
cargo condemned
cargo condemned
cargo sequestered
cargo condemned
condemned on the pretext that a letter was found in a hieroglyphic code
claim that they did not have proper role d'equipage
no role d'equipage
Irregularities with the paperwork; initially only cargo was condemned, but when Hope's owners appealed, both vessel and cargo were condemned.
Condemned in pursuance of the decree of the Agents of the Directory in Guadeloupe from 22 Jan 1797.
condemned without trial or hearing
vessel stripped and sold, and cargo also disposed of without trial
Condemned for coming from British port
Condemned for going to Port-au-Prince, which was considered a rebel port.
Commissaries demanded 15,000 worth of cargo, but while captain was trying to get that amount together, the administrator at Port de Paix broke open the holds and took its cargo.
When papers were found to be all in order, privateer still plundered the ship and took its boat.
robbed captain of all his clothes and money
From St. Martins, captain and supercargo taken to prison at Guadeloupe; condemned because supercargo had renounced the French republic when he became a US citizen (and was thus an enemy).
privateer plundered George
condemned because papers' destination was too vague (merely "The West Indies"; as well that Grenada was a British port.
condemned for lack of role d'equipage
condemned for lack of role d'equipage
condemned for lack of role d'equipage
condemned for lack of proper role d'equipage
condemned for lack of proper role d'equipage
cargo condemned
privateers dug in the salt in the hold to find jars with $11,000; put on board 5 sailors from the Farmer, a prize
Plundered by La Croyable and released
Condemned for going to Surinam, for lack of proper role d'equipage, lack of notarization (by agent in Cayenne)
plundered by captors as well as condemned
Condemned for being armed without a commission, though Mary Ann had been previously captured and her commission retained by the very consul who condemned her this time
